sn36.7:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
sn36.7:4.2: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of solitude and went to the infirmary, where
sn36.7:4.3: he sat down on the indicated seat,
sn36.7:5.1: “Mendicants, a mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.
sn36.7:5.2: This is my instruction to you.
sn36.7:6.1: And how is a mendicant mindful?
sn36.7:6.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn36.7:6.3: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn36.7:6.4: They meditate by observing an aspect of the mind …
sn36.7:6.5: They meditate by observing an aspect of principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn36.7:6.6: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.
sn36.7:7.1: And how is a mendicant aware?
sn36.7:7.2: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
sn36.7:7.3: That’s how a mendicant acts with situational awareness.
sn36.7:7.4: A mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.
sn36.7:7.5: This is my instruction to you.
sn36.7:8.1: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if pleasant feelings arise, they understand:
sn36.7:8.2: ‘A pleasant feeling has arisen in me.
sn36.7:8.6: But this body is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated.
sn36.7:8.7: So how could a pleasant feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on a body that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?”
sn36.7:8.8: They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in the body and pleasant feeling.
sn36.7:8.9: As they do so, they give up the tendency for greed for the body and pleasant feeling.
sn36.7:9.1: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if painful feelings arise, they understand:
sn36.7:9.3: ‘A painful feeling has arisen in me.
sn36.7:9.7: But this body is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated.
sn36.7:9.8: So how could a painful feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on a body that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?”
sn36.7:9.9: They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in the body and painful feeling.
sn36.7:9.10: As they do so, they give up the tendency for rigidity towards the body and painful feeling.
sn36.7:10.1: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if neutral feelings arise, they understand:
sn36.7:10.2: ‘A neutral feeling has arisen in me.
sn36.7:10.6: But this body is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated.
sn36.7:10.7: So how could a neutral feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on a body that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?”
sn36.7:10.8: They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in the body and neutral feeling.
sn36.7:10.9: As they do so, they give up the tendency to ignorance towards the body and neutral feeling.
sn36.7:11.1: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.
sn36.7:11.2: If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.
sn36.7:11.3: If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.
sn36.7:11.4: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.
sn36.7:11.5: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.
sn36.7:11.6: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.
sn36.7:11.7: Feeling the end of the body, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body.’ Feeling the end of life, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life.’
sn36.7:11.8: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life has come to an end, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’
sn36.7:12.1: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn. As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to lack of fuel.
sn36.7:12.2: In the same way, feeling the end of the body, a mendicant understands: ‘I feel the end of the body.’ Feeling the end of life, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life.’
sn36.7:12.3: Feeling the end of life, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life.’
sn36.7:12.4: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’”
